column4: well, I used right of/left of, then switched back to 'absolute' and used the values it put in theer.
But, I need to use the MacPro cos I need to 8GB of ram it has... so right now I'm trying to get at nVidia card going in it at the same time. That is the pits.
I'm running Ubuntu x64 on both.
the software I'm using (http://www.slicer.org) doesn't come in 64 bit for windows.
you have the best proprietary drivers for the ati?
yup. Grabbed them and installed them. To be fair, it may be the software itself that I'm using... the issue is a weird refreshing problem, but it only shows up under the ATI, not nvidia
yeah, it is. But I have to submit my research thesis in 4.5 weeks so I'm less about the caring why, and more about the getting it working :P
g/l man  :P
incorrect driver
there should be a backup to your xorg.conf
I rebuilt the xorg.conf using the recovery tool (which was working ok before, but not now it appears). Still happening after I pulled out the nvidia card, too.
you need to copy you xorg.conf.whatever to xorg.conf and that will get you back to what you had b4
it's in /etc/X11
Tried that and it didn't seem to work - I'll give it another shot (I have several backups).
if you did a lot of messing around with drivers it may take a while to find the right one
it is possible to revert to a 'default' xorg file though, right? the one that Ubuntu would have installed with?
ah, here we go. I reinstalled the ATI binary driver from shell and it booted again.
good good
and now I'm taking a backup of the xorg.conf before I go trying to readd the nvidia card again :P

I may have found one of my problems... When I used the 'hardware drivers' ubuntu thing to install the nvidia drivers after installing the ATI drivers, in the xorg.conf file it put in the PCI address of the card already in there (the ATI) with the nvidia driver...
just fixing that now and see how it goes.
